newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spain hopes to join NATO military command soon.
newsitem.headline: Spain hopes to join NATO military command soon.

text.p: Spanish Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar, standing beside U.S. President Bill Clinton, said on Monday he hoped Spain would join NATO's military command later this year.

Speaking after talks with Clinton on the eve of the NATO summit in Madrid, Aznar said there were some problems that needed to be resolved before Spain made a final decision on full integration into the Western defence alliance.
"We hope to join the military command of NATO once the command is fully designed and our interests are safeguarded," Aznar told reporters.
Aznar sees a full role in NATO as key to Spain securing a place among the leading nations of Europe and was anxious to reaffirm his commitment to full integration at the summit.
"We welcome Spain's intention to take her full place in NATO's integrated military structure as we complete a new command structure," Clinton said.
In negotiations with NATO on military integration, Spain is insisting on a sub-regional Iberian command which would encompass all its territory including the Canary islands.
Spain also wants control over access to the Mediterranean through the Straits of Gibraltar.
But Spanish officials have acknowledged in the run-up to the summit that some of their demands in negotiations with NATO will probably not be met.
One sticking point appears to be control over the waters between Spain's southern coast and the Canary islands in the Atlantic which NATO does not want ceded to Spanish control.
"There are some technical problems that still need to be ironed out," Aznar said.

"But I think that with the impetus given by the Madrid summit between now and the end of the year, particularly the month of December, I think we can take the definitive decision to join the full integrated military structure."
Clinton said Spain was justified in aggressively defending its interests in the negotiations with NATO but added the new structure must be militarily defensible.
